subject: Neurology

question: A mother comes to a therapist concerned that her 4-month-old infant cannot sit up alone yet. Which of the following responses is the most appropriate for the therapist?

options.text: “Your infant probably needs further examination by a specialist because, although it varies, infants can usually sit unsupported at 2 months of age.”
“Your infant probably needs further examination by a specialist because, although it varies, infants can usually sit unsupported at 3 months of age.”
“This is probably nothing to be concerned about because, although it varies, most infants can sit unsupported at 8 months of age.”
“This is probably nothing to be concerned about because, although it varies, an infant does not need to sit unsupported at 5 months at age.”

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Although sources vary widely, a child can sit unsupported usually between 4 and 8 months of age. Choices A and B are incorrect. Choice D would possibly cause the parent to worry prematurely.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Sitting unsupported at 2 months is not developmentally expected.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Sitting unsupported at 3 months is not developmentally expected.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: While true, this response is less informative and reassuring than C, which provides the normal developmental window for this skill.

subject: Pediatrics

question: In the geriatric population, __________ usually occurs after ________ is present.
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A defect in the lamina of a vertebrae usually occurs first. This defect is called spondylolysis. The vertebrae may then slip because of shear forces; this slippage is called spondylolisthesis.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The order is reversed. The defect (spondylolysis) must occur before the slippage (spondylolisthesis) can happen.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Spondyloschisis is a general term for a cleft in the vertebral arch; spondylolysis is the specific term for the pars interarticularis defect.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The order is reversed, and spondyloschisis is not the standard term.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient is referred to the therapist with a diagnosis of arthritis. What type of arthritis would the therapist expect if the patient presents with the following signs and symptoms? (1) Bilateral wrists and knees are involved, (2) pain at rest and with motion, (3) prolonged morning stiffness, and (4) crepitus.

options.text: The patient has degenerative joint disease.
It is not possible to determine with the given information.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Rheumatoid arthritis is a systemic condition commonly involving joints bilaterally. Crepitus can be associated with osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis, but rheumatoid arthritis is the most likely in this case.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Osteoarthritis is typically asymmetrical and morning stiffness is brief (< 30 minutes). Prolonged morning stiffness and bilateral involvement are hallmarks of RA.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Degenerative joint disease is another term for osteoarthritis.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The classic pattern of bilateral involvement and prolonged morning stiffness strongly points to an inflammatory arthritis like RA.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient presents to an outpatient clinic with complaints of shoulder pain. The therapist observes a painful arc between 70 degrees and 120 degrees of active abduction in the involved shoulder. This finding is most indicative of what shoulder pathology?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The “painful arc” is most indicative of shoulder impingement. The soft tissues of the shoulder are pinched under the acromion process at approximately 60 degrees to120 degrees of abduction. Pain throughout abduction active range of motion suggests acromioclavicular joint dysfunction.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: While a rotator cuff tear can cause a painful arc, impingement is the more general term for this clinical sign.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: AC joint pathology typically causes pain at the very end range of elevation (>120 degrees).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: A labrum tear is more likely to present with clicking, catching, or a sense of instability.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A tennis player receives a surgical repair of the annular ligament. Where should the therapist expect to note the most edema?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The lateral triangle (composed of the radial head, olecranon process, and lateral epicondyle) is the most likely of the choices to exhibit joint edema. Joint edema is common after a surgical procedure.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This is too general; the lateral triangle is the specific area where swelling would be most apparent.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The olecranon bursa is posterior and swelling would indicate bursitis, not necessarily joint effusion.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The ulnohumeral joint is the primary elbow joint, but swelling is most visible in the soft tissue space of the lateral triangle.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist is assessing a 40-year-old man’s balance and coordination. The following instructions are given to the patient: “Stand normally, with your eyes open. After fifteen seconds, close your eyes and maintain a normal standing posture.” Several seconds after closing his eyes, the patient nearly falls. What type of test did the patient fail?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The Romberg test is a type of equilibrium test. Equilibrium tests are usually conducted with the patient in a standing position, whereas nonequilibrium tests are performed with the patient in the supine position. Postural sway tests involve the patient standing on a computerized platform and electronically measuring the amount of sway the patient exhibits. One-legged stance tests obviously involve the patient attempting to stand on one leg during the test.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A postural sway test requires a force plate to quantify sway.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This is an equilibrium (standing balance) test, not a non-equilibrium test.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The patient was standing on both feet, not one leg.

subject: Neurology

question: A physical therapist is performing electromyographic testing. During a maximal output test of the patient’s quadricep muscle, 25% of the motor unit action potential is polyphasic. What is the significance of this finding?

options.text: It is normal in the quadricep.
It is normal in the triceps brachii, not in the quadricep.
It is normal in the biceps brachii, not in the quadricep.
It is abnormal in any muscle.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: More than 10% of polyphasic potentials in the total output of muscle is considered abnormal.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: 25% is an abnormal finding.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This finding would be abnormal in any muscle.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This finding would be abnormal in any muscle.

subject: Neurology

question: A physical therapist is ordered to examine a patient in the late stages of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. In the patient’s chart is an electromyography report and nerve conduction velocity test. What should the physical therapist not expect to find in these test results?

options.text: Decreased amplitude of motor unit action potential
Decreased duration of motor unit action potential

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: In performing these tests on patients who have this disorder, sensory potentials are generally unchanged. Motor unit potentials are increased in amplitude and duration because of variable impulse conduction time in sprouting axon terminals. Increased polyphasic potentials are usually found with increased duration.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: As motor units die off, the amplitude of the overall potential would decrease.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Duration of the motor unit action potential actually tends to increase due to reinnervation attempts.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Polyphasic potentials would be increased, not decreased, due to disorganized reinnervation.

subject: Neurology

question: A physical therapist is asked by a coworker to finish examining a patient because an emergency requires the therapist to leave. The coworker agrees and resumes the examination. The first therapist left notes titled, “sensory assessment.” Two wooden blocks identical in appearance but 1 pound different in weight are on the table in front of the patient. What test was the prior therapist most likely performing?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Barognosis is the ability to differentiate between different weights. Stereognosis is the ability to differentiate between different sizes and shapes. Graphesthesia is the ability to identify letters, numbers, or designs traced on the skin. Texture recognition is the ability to differentiate between textures such as cotton, wool, and silk.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Stereognosis involves identifying objects by feel.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Graphesthesia involves identifying figures drawn on the skin.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Texture recognition involves differentiating between different textures.

subject: Neurology

question: A patient is referred to physical therapy with a history of temporomandibular joint pain. The therapist notices that the patient is having difficulty closing his mouth against minimal resistance. With this information, which of the following muscles would not be a target for strengthening exercise to correct this deficit?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: All of the listed muscles participate in mandibular elevation with the exception of the lateral pterygoid muscle. The lateral pterygoid muscle and the suprahyoid muscles participate in mandibular depression.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The medial pterygoid is a powerful elevator of the mandible.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The temporalis is a powerful elevator of the mandible.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The masseter is a powerful elevator of the mandible.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A physical therapist is reviewing the chart of a 24-year-old woman with a diagnosis of L2 incomplete paraplegia. The physician noted that the left quadricep tendon reflex is 21. What does this information relay to the therapist?

options.text: Slight quadricep tendon with reflex testing

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: No activity = 0. Slight contraction = 1+. Normal response = 2+. Exaggerated response = 3+. Severely exaggerated = 4+.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The notation '21' does not represent a standard grading for a slight reflex.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A normal reflex is graded as 2+.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: An exaggerated reflex would be graded as 3+ or 4+.

subject: Neurology

question: A physical therapist performs the following test during an examination: With the patient lying in supine position, the therapist traces a diamond shape around the patient’s umbilicus with a sharp object. What reflex is being assessed, and what is the significance if the patient’s umbilicus does not move in response to the stimulus provided by the therapist?

options.text: Cremaster reflex, suggests upper motor neuron involvement
Superficial abdominal reflex, suggests upper motor neuron involvement
Cremaster reflex, suggests lower motor neuron involvement
Superficial abdominal reflex, suggests lower motor neuron involvement

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: When the test is performed on a patient with no motor neuron lesion, the umbilicus should move toward the stimulus. Unilateral movement suggests lower motor neuron involvement. A cremaster reflex is performed by stroking the medial thigh of a male with a sharp object. A normal response consists of superior movement of the scrotum on the ipsilateral side. An abnormal response is absence of scrotal movement on one side, which indicates possible lower motor neuron involvement. Bilateral absence of movement indicates upper motor neuron involvement.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This describes the superficial abdominal reflex, not the cremasteric reflex.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This describes the superficial abdominal reflex, and its absence suggests an UMN lesion.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The absence of this superficial reflex is indicative of an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion, not a lower motor neuron (LMN) lesion.

subject: Neurology

question: A physical therapist is asked to examine a 37-year-old man with right-side sciatica. The therapist performs a passive straight leg raise test of the right lower extremity with the knee and ankle in neutral position. In performing this test on a patient with an L5 disc protrusion, what is the lowest degree at which the therapist would expect to reproduce the patient’s symptoms?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: During a unilateral straight leg raise of the involved lower extremity, tension is placed on the sciatic nerve at approximately 35 degrees of hip flexion. At 0 degrees of hip flexion, tension is minimal to none, and tension is maximal above 70 degrees of hip flexion.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: There is no significant neural tension at 0 degrees of hip flexion.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: While pain may be present at 70 degrees, it typically begins much earlier in the range (35-70 degrees) if there is nerve root irritation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Pain at 90 degrees is more likely due to hamstring tightness rather than neural tension.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Using tests of neurologic status and motor function, an experienced physical therapist or pediatrician should be able to accurately diagnose cerebral palsy in all but the mildest cases by
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A variety of tests can be used to determine the proper diagnosis by 6 months of age.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: While some signs may be present, a definitive diagnosis is often difficult at this very early stage.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Diagnosis is typically made much earlier than 1 year of age.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Diagnosis is typically made much earlier than 2 years of age.

subject: Neurology

question: Which of the following muscles would you not expect to be affected by a C6-C7 lesion?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Choices A, B, and C all receive innervation from that branch of the brachial plexus. The triceps brachii is innervated by C7-C8.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The biceps brachii is primarily innervated by C5 and C6.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The anterior deltoid is primarily innervated by C5 and C6.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The infraspinatus is primarily innervated by C5 and C6.

subject: Neurology

question: Indicators of complex regional pain syndrome include all of the following except
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: CRPS symptoms do not include sweating, but rather dryness compared to the normal side.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Allodynia (pain from a non-painful stimulus) is a classic sign of CRPS.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Skin color changes (e.g., redness, mottling, cyanosis) are common due to autonomic dysfunction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Increased uptake on a three-phase bone scan is a diagnostic criterion for CRPS.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: What is the BEST order of these tests during neurologic patient examination?

options.text: Cognition, sensation, range of motion (ROM), reflexes, spasticity testing, manual muscle testing (MMT)
Reflexes, MMT, cognition, sensation, ROM, spasticity testing
Cognition, sensation, spasticity testing, ROM, MMT, reflexes
ROM, reflexes, sensation, MMT, ROM, spasticity testing, cognition

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Cognition, sensation, ROM, reflexes, spasticity testing, MMT is the best order. Sensory testing results can only be considered accurate if a patient’s cognitive status is known. Spasticity and manual muscle testing results are based on range of motion, so ROM must come first.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Cognition should be assessed first to ensure the patient can participate reliably in other tests.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: MMT should generally be performed after assessing ROM and spasticity.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Cognition must be assessed first.

subject: Neurology

question: The most serious complication of lower extremity thrombophlebitis is
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Thromboembolus formation is a common complication of thrombophlebitis in lower leg veins. Thrombi can pass through the heart and obstruct major pulmonary arteries.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A clot from the venous system would have to pass through the lungs first. A cerebral infarction would require the clot to cross into the arterial system, which is rare (e.g., via a patent foramen ovale).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A myocardial infarction is typically caused by a clot in the coronary arteries, not an embolus from the venous system.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: A kidney infection (pyelonephritis) is typically caused by bacteria and is not a direct complication of a DVT.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: A 50-year-old man has a persistent cough, purulent sputum, abnormal dilation of bronchi, more frequent involvement of the lower lobe than the right, hemoptysis, and reduced forced vital capacity. What is the most likely pulmonary dysfunction?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: These are signs and symptoms of a patient with bronchiectasis.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: While chronic bronchitis involves a persistent cough and sputum, the key finding here is "abnormal dilation of bronchi," which is the definition of bronchiectasis.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Emphysema is characterized by destruction of alveolar walls and air-trapping, not bronchial dilation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction and inflammation.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: Which of the following are tests for peripheral arterial involvement in a patient with complaints of calf musculature pain?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Claudication is a lack of blood flow. This test is performed by having a patient walk on a treadmill and recording how long the patient can walk before the onset of symptoms. Homan’s sign is a test performed to see whether a patient may have a deep vein thrombosis. The percussion test is designed to assess the integrity of the greater saphenous vein. Hoffa’s test checks the integrity of the Achilles tendon.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Homan's sign is a test for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), a venous condition, not an arterial one.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The percussion test assesses venous valve competency.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Hoffa's test is not a standard test for arterial involvement; it is sometimes associated with fat pad impingement in the knee.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: A patient presents to a clinic with decreased tidal volume (TV). What is the most likely pulmonary function?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A decreased tidal volume is caused by a restrictive lung dysfunction. An increased tidal volume is caused by an obstructive lung dysfunction. Choices A and C and D are in the family of obstructive pulmonary disease.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: COPD is an obstructive disease, which is typically associated with an increased, not decreased, tidal volume at rest due to air trapping.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Restrictive lung disease limits lung expansion, resulting in a decreased tidal volume.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Emphysema is a type of COPD (obstructive disease).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Asthma is an obstructive disease.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: A patient presents with tachypnea, corpulmonale, hypoxemia, rales on inspiration, and decreased diffusing capacity. What is the probable cause?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: These signs are consistent with restrictive lung dysfunction. All other choices are obstructive lung dysfunctions.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: COPD (obstructive disease) would more likely present with signs of air trapping (e.g., barrel chest) and wheezing rather than inspiratory rales.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Asthma (obstructive) is characterized by wheezing due to bronchoconstriction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Emphysema (obstructive) would present with diminished breath sounds and signs of hyperinflation.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: A physician instructs the therapist to educate a patient about the risk factors of atherosclerosis. Which of the following is the most inappropriate list?

options.text: Diabetes, male gender, and excessive alcohol
Genetic predisposition, smoking, and sedentary lifestyle
Hypertension is a risk factor in atherosclerosis

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The question asks for the most *inappropriate list*. Options A, B, and C all list multiple valid risk factors. Option D is a single true statement, not a list, making it the answer that doesn't fit the question's format. All items listed in A, B, C, and D are indeed risk factors or true statements about atherosclerosis.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: All are well-established risk factors for atherosclerosis.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: All are well-established risk factors for atherosclerosis.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Both stress and a lack of exercise are significant risk factors.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: A therapist is ordered by a physician to treat a patient with congestive heart failure in an outpatient cardiac rehabilitation facility. Which of the following signs and symptoms should the therapist not expect?

options.text: Decreased preload of the right heart

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Patients with congestive heart failure often develop an enlarged heart because of the burden of an increased preload and afterload. A decreased preload would not be expected.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Mitral valve stenosis can be a cause of congestive heart failure, leading to a backup of pressure.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Orthopnea (shortness of breath when lying flat) is a classic symptom of CHF due to pulmonary congestion.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Pulmonary edema is a hallmark sign of left-sided congestive heart failure.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: At a team meeting, the respiratory therapist informs the rest of the team that the patient, just admitted to the subacute floor, experienced breathing difficulty in the acute care department. The respiratory therapist describes the breathing problem as a pause before exhaling after a full inspiration. Which of the following is the therapist describing?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Apneusis can be described as an inspiratory cramp, characterized by a prolonged inspiratory phase followed by a pause. Orthopnea is difficulty with breathing in a lying position. Eupnea is normal breathing. Apnea is the absence of breathing.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Apnea is the complete cessation of breathing.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Orthopnea is shortness of breath that occurs when lying flat.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Eupnea is the term for normal, quiet breathing.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: A therapist is performing chest physiotherapy on a patient who is coughing up a significant amount of sputum. The therapist later describes the quality of the sputum in his notes as mucoid. This description tells other personnel which of the following?

options.text: The sputum has a foul odor.
The sputum is clear or white in color.
The patient has a possible bronchopulmonary infection.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Mucoid sputum is clear or white and is not usually associated with infection. Thick sputum is referred to as tenacious. Foul-smelling sputum is called fetid and is often associated with infection.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Thick sputum would be described as tenacious.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Foul-smelling sputum would be described as fetid.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Purulent (pus-containing) sputum, which is typically yellow or green, suggests infection. Mucoid sputum does not.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: A therapist is sent to provide passive range of motion to a patient in the intensive care unit. The chart reveals that the patient is suffering from pulmonary edema. The charge nurse informs the therapist that the patient is coughing up a thin, white sputum with a pink tint. Which of the following terms best describes this sputum?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Frothy sputum is thin and white or has a slight pink color. This type of sputum is common with pulmonary edema. Purulent sputum resembles pus, with a yellow or green color. Mucopurulent sputum is yellow to light green in color. Rusty sputum is a rust-colored sputum often associated with pneumonia.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Purulent sputum is pus-like and indicates infection, typically yellow or green.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Mucopurulent sputum is a mix of mucus and pus, also indicating infection.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Rusty-colored sputum is classic for pneumococcal pneumonia.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: Strengthening exercises for persons with hemophilia should

options.text: Begin as soon as a joint bleed is recognized
Be increased using high repetition, low load PREs
Only occur in joints that demonstrate muscle weakness

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: All exercises for this population should avoid the possibility of joint bleeding. High velocity isokinetics or high weight, low repetition exercises are a contraindication. Provided there is no active bleeding, exercise to any joint is indicated.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Exercise is contraindicated during an acute joint bleed (hemarthrosis).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: While high-velocity isokinetics should be avoided, isokinetic exercise at slower, controlled speeds may be appropriate in later stages of rehabilitation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: A total body conditioning program is important, not just exercising weak joints.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient with cryoglobulinemia presents to outpatient physical therapy with complaints of lumbar pain. Which of the following should the physical therapist avoid during intervention for this diagnosis?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: In cryoglobulinemia, ischemia can be caused by abnormal blood proteins gelling at low temperatures. Moist heat will not affect this condition.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Heat is not contraindicated and may be beneficial for pain relief.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Weight-bearing exercises are not contraindicated.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Muscle energy techniques are not contraindicated.

subject: Other

question: A physical therapist is assessing the endurance of a 12-year-old female with cystic fibrosis. Which objective screening tool would be most appropriate to quantify the patient’s endurance level?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The Six Minute Walk Test is used to determine a patient’s functional exercise capacity.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The Tinetti POMA is primarily a measure of balance and gait to assess fall risk, not endurance.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A VO2 Max test is a maximal exercise test requiring specialized equipment and is not a simple screening tool for functional endurance.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The Romberg test is a screen for balance and proprioception, not endurance.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: A physical therapist is performing an examination for an infant that has recently been diagnosed with a congenital heart defect. Which of the following clinical signs would not likely be present?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: An infant with a congenital heart defect often has a labored breathing pattern, increased respiratory rate, diaphoresis, tachycardia, edema, and feeding difficulties.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Poor weight gain is common due to feeding difficulties and increased metabolic demand.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Respiratory rate would be increased (tachypnea), not decreased, as the body tries to compensate for poor oxygenation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Lower extremity swelling (edema) can occur due to fluid backup from heart failure.

subject: Cardiopulmonary

question: Besides the anterolateral abdominal muscles, which muscle assists in forced expiration, coughing, sneezing, vomiting, urinating, defecating, and fixation of the trunk during strong movements of the upper limb?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The pelvic diaphragm is composed of the levator ani and coccygeus muscles. This pelvic diaphragm assists in forced expiration, coughing, sneezing, vomiting, urinating, defecating, and fixation of the trunk during strong movements of the upper limb.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The piriformis is a deep external rotator of the hip.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The trapezius is a large muscle of the back and shoulder girdle.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The gluteus maximus is a primary hip extensor.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Which muscle does NOT flex the knee and extend the hip?

options.text: Hamstring portion of the adductor magnus
Long head of the biceps femoris

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: All four muscles are hamstring muscles of the posterior thigh. Only the hamstring portion of adductor magnus does not cross the knee. It inserts on the adductor tubercle of the femur. The other three muscles cross the knee posteriorly and therefore flex the knee.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The semitendinosus is a hamstring muscle that flexes the knee and extends the hip.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The long head of the biceps femoris is a hamstring muscle that flexes the knee and extends the hip.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The semimembranosus is a hamstring muscle that flexes the knee and extends the hip.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: History taking revealed that a patient experiences pain after horseback riding or skating. The pain is located over the anteromedial thigh and is aggravated by resisted abduction. What is the MOST likely preliminary diagnosis?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Adductor longus, rectus femoris, and iliopsoas are the muscles typically involved in hip muscle strain/tendonitis/tendinosis. Pain is aggravated by activity or in resistance testing. Adductor strains arise in horseback riders, skiers, and skaters.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Piriformis syndrome would typically cause buttock pain, potentially with sciatic nerve irritation, and be aggravated by resisted external rotation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Trochanteric bursitis would cause pain over the lateral hip.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Avascular necrosis of the hip typically presents as groin pain and is less likely to be aggravated by resisted abduction.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient has dull posterior hip pain radiating down the leg. He says that he has a limp and that his pain is aggravated by turning his leg outside or with deep pressure near the middle of the right buttock. What is the MOST likely preliminary diagnosis?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: History and type/site of pain are the most important features to direct the examination. Piriformis irritation often presents as dull posterior hip pain radiating down the leg, mimicking radicular symptoms. Limping, pain aggravated by active external rotation, or passive internal rotation or palpation of sciatic notch is a salient feature.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Trochanteric bursitis causes pain over the lateral aspect of the hip.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Adductor strain causes pain in the anteromedial thigh/groin.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Avascular necrosis typically presents with groin pain and is less likely to be aggravated by palpation in the buttock.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: What is the BEST imaging modality for detecting the changes in the articular cartilage seen with chondromalacia patella?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: While direct visualization of articular cartilage is possible with both MRI and CT, MRI gives better resolution and detail. Neither bone scan nor plain film radiography will show the cartilage.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Plain film x-rays show bone well but do not visualize soft tissues like cartilage.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: A bone scan shows areas of increased bone metabolism and is used to detect fractures, infections, or tumors, not cartilage changes.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: CT provides excellent detail of bone but is less effective than MRI for visualizing soft tissue like articular cartilage.

subject: Other

question: Which of the following imaging modalities does NOT give a radiation dose to the patient?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: MRI does not provide any form of radiation to the patient.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: CT scans use a significant dose of ionizing radiation (x-rays).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Mammography uses low-dose ionizing radiation (x-rays).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: A bone scan involves injecting a radioactive tracer, which exposes the patient to ionizing radiation.

subject: Other

question: A therapist is examining a 3-year-old child, who is positioned as follows: supine, hips flexed to 90 degrees, hips fully adducted, and knees flexed. The therapist passively abducts and raises the thigh, applying an anterior shear force to the hip joint. A click at 30 degrees of abduction is noted by the therapist. What orthopedic test is the therapist performing, and what is its significance?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Ortolani’s test is used to detect a congenitally dislocated hip in an infant. Choices B and C are common meniscus damage tests for the knee. Choice D is performed by placing the infant in supine position with the hip flexed to 90 degrees and slight abduction and the knee flexed to 90 degrees. The examiner then moves the infant’s hip anterior and posterior in an effort to detect abnormal joint mobility.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Appley's tests are for meniscal tears in the knee.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The McMurray test is for meniscal tears in the knee.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The piston test (telescoping) checks for hip instability, but the specific maneuver described is the Ortolani test for reducing a dislocated hip.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A teenager comes to an outpatient facility with complaints of pain at the tibial tubercle when playing basketball. The therapist notices that the tubercles are abnormally pronounced on bilateral knees. What condition does the patient most likely have?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Osgood-Schlatter disease is severe tendinitis of the patellar tendon. It is characterized by pronounced tibial tubercles. The increased size of the tubercles is attributed to the patella tendon pulling away from its insertion. Jumper’s knees (or normal patella tendinitis) does not necessarily present with tubercle enlargement. Sever’s disease involves the Achilles tendon pulling away from its insertion on the calcaneus.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Jumper's knee (patellar tendinopathy) involves pain at the inferior pole of the patella, not necessarily a pronounced tibial tubercle.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: An ACL sprain is a ligamentous injury inside the knee joint and does not cause prominence of the tibial tubercle.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Sever's disease is an apophysitis of the calcaneus (heel bone).

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient presents to physical therapy with complaints of right hip due to osteoarthritis. Which of the following is not true about the signs and symptoms of arthritis?

options.text: Osteoarthritis causes pain that is usually symmetric because it is a systemic condition.
Osteoarthritis is not usually more painful in the morning.
Osteoarthritis commonly involves the distal interphalangeal joint.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Choice A describes rheumatoid arthritis, a systemic condition. All of the other choices are signs and symptoms of osteoarthritis (OA). Sometimes OA can involve symmetric joints, but it is not systemic.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Pain in OA is typically worse with activity and at the end of the day. Morning stiffness is brief (< 30 minutes).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The DIP joints (Heberden's nodes) are a classic location for osteoarthritis.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: OA is a 'wear and tear' arthritis that predominantly affects weight-bearing joints like the hips and knees.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Which of the following is used to treat a patient with physical therapy with a diagnosis of Dupuytren’s contracture?

options.text: Work simulator set for squatting activities

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Dupuytren’s contracture is a progressive thickening of the palmar aponeurosis of the hand. The progression is gradual, and the interphalangeal joints are pulled into flexion.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A CPM machine for the knee would be used after knee surgery.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: A work simulator would be used for work hardening and is irrelevant to this condition.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: A dumbbell is for strengthening and would not treat a flexion contracture.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A 17-year-old football player is referred to the outpatient physical therapy with a diagnosis of a recent third-degree medial collateral ligament sprain of the knee. The patient wishes to return to playing football as soon as possible. Which protocol below is the best?

options.text: Fit the patient with a brace that prevents him from actively moving the knee into the last available 20 degrees of extension. Prescribe general lower extremity strengthening with the exception of side-lying hip adduction.
Do not fit the patient with a brace. All lower extremity strengthening exercises are indicated.
Fit the patient with a brace that prevents him from actively moving the knee into the last available 20 degrees of extension. Avoid all open-chain strengthening for the lower extremity.
Do not fit the patient with a brace. Prescribe general lower extremity strengthening with the exception of side-lying hip adduction.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The screw home mechanism that is present in the last few degrees of terminal knee extension stresses the MCL. Side-lying hip adduction also places the MCL in a position of stretch.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: A grade 3 sprain is a complete tear, and a brace is typically required for stability. Side-lying hip adduction would stress the healing MCL and should be avoided.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: There is no reason to avoid all open-chain strengthening exercises; many can be performed safely.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: A brace is indicated for a grade 3 sprain to protect the ligament during healing.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: During an examination, the therapist taps on the flexor retinaculum of the patient’s wrist, which causes tingling in the thumb. What test is this? For what condition does it screen?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A positive Tinel’s sign screens for carpal tunnel syndrome when the tapping force is performed over the carpal tunnel itself. In Phalen’s test, the therapist places the patient’s wrists in maximal flexion and holds for 1 minute. The test is positive if there is paresthesia in the median nerve distribution. The Finkelstein test screens for de Quervain’s disease by allowing the patient to make a fist with the thumb wrapped in the fingers. The test is positive if there is pain over the adductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Phalen's test involves sustained wrist flexion, not tapping.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Finkelstein's test involves ulnar deviation with the thumb in a fist and screens for de Quervain's tenosynovitis.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Tinel's sign at the wrist screens for carpal tunnel (median nerve), not de Quervain's.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient is recovering from a recent total hip replacement on the right side. During ambulation, the patient demonstrates a right lateral trunk lean when in the single-limb stance phase of gait. This type of gait deviation is usually due to weakness of the
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The hip strategy is used to compensate for large movements in the center of mass, and the ankle strategy is used to compensate for small movements.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Weakness of the left hip abductors would cause a left trunk lean during left stance phase.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Adductor weakness does not cause a lateral trunk lean.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Adductor weakness does not cause a lateral trunk lean.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: An infant with a greenstick fracture of the right clavicle is referred to a physical therapist. The infant sustained the injury during birth. The therapist should

options.text: This scenario describes a greenstick fracture, which is common in young people. In a comminuted fracture, the bone is broken into pieces. An example of an avulsion fracture is when the tibial tuberosity is pulled off the tibia. A bone that has a segmental fracture is fractured in two places.

Because of the unreliable history obtained in the evaluation, the therapist at least should make a quick assessment of range of motion and strength before the patient attempts to stand. Sit-to-stand transfer should then be assessed in front of the lift chair before the patient attempts to ambulate.
The method used in Choice A is the safest. The method used in Choice C is too unstable.
This is a non-displaced fracture and requires no intervention from the therapist.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Because of the unreliable history obtained in the evaluation, the therapist at least should make a quick assessment of range of motion and strength before the patient attempts to stand. Sit-to-stand transfer should then be assessed in front of the lift chair before the patient attempts to ambulate.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This option is a description of fracture types, not an action plan.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This option is a comment on another question's choices, not a relevant answer here.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: While it is a stable fracture, PT intervention is often indicated to instruct parents on safe handling and positioning to promote healing and prevent further injury.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A high school student presents to the emergency room with a dislocated elbow. What is the most likely mechanism of injury?

options.text: A fall on an extended elbow
A direct blow to the elbow
A twisting injury to the elbow
A fall on a flexed elbow

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Nursemaid’s elbow is defined as dissociation of the radial head from the annular ligament. Choices A and D are usually to the result of a fall on an extended elbow. Erb’s palsy is due to cervical trauma.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: A direct blow is more likely to cause a fracture.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: A twisting injury is a less common mechanism for elbow dislocation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Falling on a flexed elbow is not the typical mechanism; falling on an outstretched hand with the elbow extended is.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A child presents to physical therapy with a diagnosis of right Sever’s disease. What joint should be the focus of the therapist’s examination?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Sever’s disease is traction apophysitis of the gastrocnemius tendon in children. In other words, the gastrocnemius attempts to pull away from the calcaneus, causing an inflammatory condition.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The knee is not the site of Sever's disease.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The hip is not the site of Sever's disease.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The wrist is not the site of Sever's disease.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A 10-year-old boy presents to outpatient physical therapy with complaints of diffuse pain in the right hip, thigh, and knee joint. The patient was involved in a motor vehicle accident 3 weeks ago. He is also obese and has significant atrophy in the right quadricep. The right lower extremity is held by the patient in the position of flexion, abduction, and lateral rotation. Which of the signs and symptoms are most consistent with a slipped capital epiphysis?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The signs and symptoms are most consistent with a slipped capital epiphysis. Bursitis presents with pain located over the bursa and is associated with overuse or rheumatoid arthritis. Avascular necrosis most frequently involves men 30 to 50 years of age. Septic arthritis is usually present in children 2 years of age or younger and often is due to steroid use or fever.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Trochanteric bursitis would present with localized tenderness over the lateral hip, not the diffuse pain pattern described.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Avascular necrosis is a possibility but SCFE is more common in this age group and presents with this classic limb positioning.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Septic arthritis would typically present with systemic signs of infection like a high fever and malaise, which are not mentioned.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A high-school athlete is considering whether to have an anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction. The therapist explains the importance of this ligament, especially in a person that is young and athletic. Which of the statements below is correct in describing part of the function of the anterior cruciate ligament?

options.text: The anterior cruciate ligament prevents excessive posterior roll of the femoral condyles during flexion of the femur at the knee joint.
The anterior cruciate ligament prevents excessive anterior roll of the femoral condyles during flexion of the femur at the knee joint.
The anterior cruciate ligament prevents excessive posterior roll of the femoral condyles during extension of the femur at the knee joint.
The anterior cruciate ligament prevents excessive anterior roll of the femoral condyles during extension of the femur at the knee joint.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The anterior cruciate ligament prevents excessive posterior roll of the femoral condyles during extension of the femur at the knee joint.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This describes a function more related to the PCL and the opposite motion (flexion).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This is a duplicate of option A and is incorrect.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The ACL's primary role is to resist anterior tibial translation and posterior femoral translation, especially near extension.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Which tendon is most commonly involved with lateral epicondylitis?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The extensor carpi radialis brevis absorbs most of the stress placed on the involved upper extremity in the position of wrist flexion, ulnar deviation, forearm pronation, and elbow extension (as with a backhand swing in tennis).

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: While the ECRL can be involved, the ECRB is more commonly the primary site of pathology in lateral epicondylitis.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The brachioradialis is primarily an elbow flexor and is not typically involved in lateral epicondylitis.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The extensor digitorum is part of the common extensor tendon but the ECRB is the most frequently implicated.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A patient who has suffered a zone 2 rupture of the extensor tendon of the third digit presents to physical therapy. This patient had a surgical fixation of the avulsed tendon. During the period of immobilization, which of the following deformities is most likely to develop?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Swan-neck deformity involves hyperextension of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint and flexion of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. Splinting to avoid this deformity is the treatment of choice. Boutonnière deformity involves flexion of the PIP joint and DIP joint hyperextension. Dupuytren’s contracture is contracture of the palmar aponeurosis. Claw hand is the result of laceration of the ulnar nerve.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A Boutonnière deformity results from a rupture of the central slip of the extensor tendon over the PIP joint.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Claw hand is a deformity resulting from combined median and ulnar nerve palsy.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Dupuytren's contracture is a progressive fibrosis of the palmar fascia.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Which of the following muscle tendons most commonly sublux in patients who suffer from rheumatoid arthritis?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The extensor carpi ulnaris is frequently subluxed after rupture of the triangular fibrocartilage complex. Subluxation leads to many mechanical changes in the wrist that are common in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The flexor tendons are less prone to subluxation than the extensor tendons in the wrist.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The ECRL is less commonly subluxed than the ECU.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The FPL is not a common site for subluxation in RA.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A therapist is scheduled to examine a patient with a chronic condition of “hammer toes.” Where should the therapist not expect to find callus formation?

options.text: The distal tips of the toes
The superior surface of the interphalangeal joints
The inferior surface of the interphalangeal joints

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A patient with hammer toes exhibits hyperextension of the distal interphalangeal joints and metatarsophalangeal joints. This causes calluses on the distal tips and superior surfaces from rubbing against shoes, and on the metatarsal heads from increased pressure. The inferior surface of the IP joints is not a typical pressure area.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Calluses can form on the tips of the toes due to pressure against the shoe.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Calluses form on the top of the PIP joints from rubbing against the shoe.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Increased pressure on the metatarsal heads is common with hammer toes, leading to callus formation.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Each of these factors influences the probability of scoliosis curve progression in the skeletally immature patient except
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Race has no role in progression of scoliosis, idiopathic or congenital.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The initial magnitude of the curve (Cobb angle) is a primary predictor of progression.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Females have a significantly higher risk of curve progression than males.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The patient's age and skeletal maturity (e.g., Risser sign) are critical factors; younger patients with more growth remaining have a higher risk of progression.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: The child with clubfoot will have
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: In clubfoot, the calcaneus is small, the hindfoot is in varus, and there is equinas (fixed plantar flexion) of the ankle. There is typically no tibial involvement.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The calcaneus is typically small and underdeveloped.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The forefoot is in varus (adduction), not valgus (abduction).
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Significant tibial shortening is not a characteristic feature of clubfoot.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Which of the following is a contraindication to ultrasound at a 1-MHz sound head?

options.text: Over a recently surgically repaired tendon

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A therapist can use ultrasound with all of the other choices. Performing an ultrasound over a cemented metal implant is also a contraindication. However, with any ultrasound technique, treatment should be stopped if the patient feels pain.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Ultrasound over non-cemented metal implants is not contraindicated as the metal does not heat up significantly.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Pulsed, non-thermal ultrasound is often used to promote healing over a repaired tendon.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The quadriceps muscle belly is a common and appropriate site for ultrasound application.

subject: Other

question: While obtaining the history from a 62-year-old woman weighing 147 pounds, the therapist discovers that the patient has a history of rheumatoid arthritis. The physician’s order is for outpatient physical therapy that includes continuous traction due to an L2 disc protrusion. What is the best course of action for the therapist?

options.text: Consult with the physician because rheumatoid arthritis is a contraindication.
Apply intermittent traction instead of continuous traction.
Use continuous traction with the weight setting at 110 pounds.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Choices A and C are incorrect because rheumatoid arthritis is a contraindication for continuous or intermittent traction. Choice D is incorrect for the same reason as well as that a 110-pound setting is too great for a 147-pound patient.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Following an order with a clear contraindication is unsafe and unprofessional.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Rheumatoid arthritis is a contraindication for any form of mechanical traction due to potential ligamentous instability.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This is incorrect due to both the contraindication (RA) and the excessive weight (well over 50% of body weight).

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: A 25-year-old woman has been referred to a physical therapist by an orthopedist because of low back pain. The therapist is performing an ultrasound at the L3 level of the posterior back when the patient suddenly informs the therapist that she is looking forward to having her third child. On further investigation, the therapist discovers that the patient is in the first trimester of pregnancy. Which of the following is the best course of action for the therapist?

options.text: Change the settings of the ultrasound from continuous to pulsed.
Continue with the continuous setting because first-trimester pregnancy is not a contraindication.
Cease treatment, notify the patient’s orthopedic physician, and document the mistake.
Send the patient to the gynecologist for an immediate sonogram.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The therapist should notify the referring physician. The mistake should be documented and the patient informed. The referring physician can determine the need for a consultation with him or her or an obstetrician.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Changing to pulsed does not eliminate the contraindication. Ultrasound over the low back is contraindicated during pregnancy.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Pregnancy is an absolute contraindication for ultrasound over the low back.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: It is not within the PT's scope to order a sonogram; the first step is to cease treatment and inform the referring physician.

subject: Other

question: The therapist routinely places ice on the ankle of a patient with an acute ankle sprain. Ice application has many therapeutic benefits. Which of the following is the body’s first response to application of ice?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Local vasoconstriction is the first response. Nerve conduction velocity decreases after approximately 5 minutes of ice application.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Decreased nerve conduction velocity occurs, but it is a slightly slower response than the initial vasoconstriction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Decreased sensitivity (analgesia) is a therapeutic goal that occurs after a period of cooling.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Pain is a sensation reported by the patient, often an initial sharp cold feeling, but vasoconstriction is the physiological first response.

subject: Other

question: Which of the following theories supports the use of a transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) unit for sensory level pain control?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This theory supports the use of a TENS unit for sensory level pain control. The activation of the larger fibers decreases the amount of sensory information traveling to the brain.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Sensory interaction theory is not a standard theory for pain modulation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Central summation refers to the amplification of pain signals in the CNS, which is what TENS aims to inhibit, not what it is based on.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Sensory integration theory relates to how the brain processes sensory information for functional use, primarily in a pediatric/neurological context.

subject: Other

question: Which of the following tissues absorbs the least amount of an ultrasound beam at 1 MHz?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Tissue with a high collagen content absorbs more ultrasound. Bone absorbs the most ultrasound.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Bone has the highest absorption coefficient and absorbs the most ultrasound energy.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Skin has a moderate absorption coefficient.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Muscle has a moderate absorption coefficient, lower than bone but higher than blood.

subject: Other

question: The therapist decides to use electrical stimulation to increase a patient’s quadriceps strength. Which of the following is the best protocol?

options.text: Electrodes placed over the superior/lateral quadriceps and the vastus medialis obliquus; stimulation on for 15 seconds, then off for 15 seconds
Electrodes over the femoral nerve in the proximal quadriceps and the vastus medialis obliquus; stimulation on for 50 seconds, then off for 10 seconds
Electrodes over the vastus medialis obliquus and superior/lateral quadriceps; stimulation frequency set between 50 to 80 hertz, pps
Electrodes over the femoral nerve in the proximal quadriceps and the vastus medialis obliquus; stimulation frequency set between 50 to 80 hertz, pps

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Correct electrode placement is over the motor points of the involved muscle. On/off cycle time is usually between 1:3 and 1:5. Fused tetany of a muscle usually occurs between 50 to 80 hertz or pps (sources vary).

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A 1:1 on/off ratio (15 on, 15 off) would lead to very rapid muscle fatigue.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: A 5:1 on/off ratio (50 on, 10 off) is inappropriate and would cause extreme fatigue.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Stimulating over the femoral nerve is one approach, but placing electrodes over the motor points of the muscle belly is also common and effective. The key is the frequency for tetany.

subject: Other

question: A therapist should consider using a form of treatment other than moist heat application on the posterior lumbar region of all of the following patients except

options.text: Patient with a history of hemophilia
Patient with a history of malignant cancer under the site of heat application
Patient with a history of Raynaud’s phenomenon
Patient with a history including many years of steroid therapy

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Raynaud’s phenomenon is a vasospastic disorder of the vessels of the distal parts of the extremities. Patients with Raynaud’s phenomenon do not respond well to cold treatment. Choice B is incorrect because it is believed that moist heat may encourage more rapid growth of cancer. Choice D is incorrect because prolonged use of steroids may cause capillaries to lose their integrity, which compromises the body’s ability to dissipate heat. Choice A is incorrect because moist heat may encourage hemorrhaging in patients with hemophilia by causing vasodilation.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Heat causes vasodilation and is contraindicated over an area with a bleeding disorder like hemophilia.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: Heat is contraindicated over a site of known malignancy as it can increase metabolic rate and blood flow.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Long-term steroid use can make skin fragile and compromise its ability to dissipate heat, increasing the risk of burns.

subject: Other

question: A 50-year-old woman has been receiving treatment in the hospital for increased edema in the right upper extremity. The therapist has treated the patient for the past 3 weeks with an intermittent compression pump equipped with a multicompartment compression sleeve. The patient’s average blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg. The daily sessions are 3 hours in duration. The pump is set at 50 mm Hg, 40 mm Hg, and 30 mm Hg (distal to proximal) for 30 seconds, on and off for 15 seconds. The therapist decides to change the parameters. Of the following changes, which is the most likely to increase the efficiency of treatment?

options.text: Place the patient in a seated position with the right upper extremity in a dependent position versus supine position.
Increase the maximal pressure from 50 mm Hg to 60 mm Hg.
Change the on/off time to 15 seconds on and 45 seconds off.
Equalize the sleeve compartments versus having greater pressure distally.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Although the change may be minimal, increasing the maximal pressure to 60 mm Hg is the most likely choice to have a positive effect on edema reduction. The pressure, however, should not exceed the diastolic pressure of the patient. Choice A is not the right choice because placing the extremity in a dependent position causes the pump to work against gravity. Choice C is an incorrect choice because decreasing the on time means that the extremity receives compression for a shorter period. Choice D is an incorrect choice because greater pressure distally is more likely to move fluid than equal pressure throughout the sleeve.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A dependent position would increase edema due to gravity, making the pump less effective.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Decreasing the on time reduces the total time the limb is under compression, making it less effective.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Sequential compression with greater pressure distally is more effective at moving fluid proximally than equal pressure.

subject: Other

question: A therapist is aspiring to choose to work with her patient using fluidotherapy rather than paraffin wax. The patient has a lack of range of motion and also needs to decrease hypersensitivity. There are no open wounds on the hand to be treated. Which of the following would not be an advantage of using fluidotherapy versus paraffin wax in the above scenario?

options.text: The therapist can assist range of motion manually while the patient has his hand in the fluidotherapy and not while in the paraffin wax.
The fluidotherapy can be used to assist in desensitzation by adjusting air intensity.
The fluidotherapy can be provided at the same time as dynamic splinting, and this cannot be done while in paraffin wax.
The fingers can be bound, to assist gaining finger flexion, with tape while in fluidotherapy and not in paraffin wax.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The fingers can be bound in paraffin wax as well as in fluidotherapy. When using this technique, the hand remains stationary throughout the heating process, which is necessary for paraffin to be most effective (when using the standard method of dipping the hand and wrapping with plastic and a towel).

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This is a key advantage of fluidotherapy; it allows for active and active-assisted ROM during the heat application.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The dry particles in fluidotherapy provide mechanical stimulation which is excellent for desensitization.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Dynamic splinting can be used concurrently with fluidotherapy, which is not possible with the dip-and-wrap paraffin method.

subject: Other

question: A therapist is treating a 35-year-old man who has suffered loss of motor control in the right lower extremity due to peripheral neuropathy. The therapist applies biofeedback electrodes to the right quadricep in an effort to increase control and strength of this muscle group. The biofeedback can help achieve this goal in all of the following ways except

options.text: Providing visual input for the patient to know how hard he is contracting the right quadricep
Assisting the patient in recruitment of more motor units in the right quadricep
Providing a measure of torque in the right quadricep
Providing the therapist input on the patient’s ability and effort in contracting the right quadricep

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The EMG does not record torque. It assists by showing a linear relationship between the EMG and the force produced by the muscle during an isometric contraction.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Providing visual or auditory feedback on muscle activation is the primary purpose of biofeedback.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: By providing feedback, the patient can learn to improve their recruitment of motor units.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The therapist can use the biofeedback signal to objectively monitor the patient's effort and muscle activation.

subject: Other

question: A patient is receiving electrical stimulation for muscle strengthening of the left quadricep. One electrode from one lead wire, 4 x 4 inches in size, is placed on the anterior proximal portion of the left quadricep. Each of two other electrodes from one lead wire are 2 x 2 inches in size. One of the electrodes is placed on the inferior medial side of the left quadricep and one on the inferior lateral side of the left quadricep. This is an example of what type of electrode configuration?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This is an example of a bipolar configuration. Another form of bipolar configuration is to have two electrodes of equal size, each from a different lead wire. In a monopolar configuration, one smaller electrode is placed over the intended site and a larger electrode is placed some distance away. The stimulation is perceived by the patient, in this case, only under the smaller electrode. In a quadripolar configuration, two electrodes coming from two different lead wires are placed over the intended area.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: A monopolar setup uses one active electrode over the target and a larger dispersive electrode placed elsewhere.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Tripolar is not a standard term for electrode configuration.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: A quadripolar setup involves two channels (four electrodes) crossing over each other, as in interferential current.

subject: Other

question: In comparing the use of cold pack and hot pack treatments, which of the following statements is false?

options.text: Cold packs penetrate more deeply than hot packs.
Cold increases the viscosity of fluid and heat decreases the viscosity of fluid.
Cold decreases spasm by decreasing sensitivity to muscle spindles and heat decreases spasm by decreasing nerve conduction velocity.
Cold decreases the rate of oxygen uptake, and heat increases the rate of oxygen uptake.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Choice C is correct. Heat decreases spasm by causing the vessels to dilate, which brings more blood (containing oxygen) to the area. Cold decreases spasm by decreasing sensitivity of the muscle spindles.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This is true. Cold can achieve a greater depth of penetration than superficial heat.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This is true. Cold increases viscosity, while heat decreases it.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This is true. Cold decreases local metabolic rate, while heat increases it.

subject: Other

question: A patient is being treated with iontophoresis, driving dexamethasone, for inflammation around the lateral epicondyle of the left elbow. The therapist is careful when setting the parameters and with cleaning the site of electrode application to prevent a possible blister. This possibility is not as strong with some other forms of electrical stimulation, but with iontophoresis using a form of __________, precautions must be taken to ensure that the patient does not receive a mild burn or blister during the treatment session.
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Iontophoresis uses direct current to drive medication through the skin by repelling ions. For example, if a medication is positively charged, it can be driven by the anode (the positive electrode); if a medication is negatively charged, it can be driven by the cathode (the negative electrode).

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Alternating current involves a constant change in polarity and would not effectively drive ions in one direction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Pulsed current has interruptions and is not as effective for iontophoresis as continuous direct current.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: TENS uses a pulsed current and is designed for sensory or motor stimulation, not for driving medication.

subject: Other

question: A physician has ordered a specific type of electrical stimulation that utilizes a frequency of 2500 Hz with a base frequency at 50 Hz to achieve fused tetany. What type of electrical stimulation has the physician ordered?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This is an example of Russian stimulation.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Iontophoresis uses direct current to deliver medication.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: TENS uses lower frequencies and is primarily for pain control.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This is not a standard term for a type of electrical stimulation.

subject: Other

question: A physical therapist who is pregnant has been studying the use of transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation during labor and birth to decrease pain perception. Which of the following is the most effective technique in this situation?

options.text: Place the electrodes over the upper abdominals during the first stages of labor and over the lower abdominals during the latter stages.
Place the electrodes over the paraspinals at the L5 level and S1 level throughout labor and delivery.
Place the electrodes in a V pattern above the pubic region
Place electrodes over the paraspinals at the L1 and S1 level initially during labor, and over the pubic region during the latter stages.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This is the most common placement suggested by sources used in preparation of this book. Spinal level varies, but the overall consensus is that the electrodes are placed higher and on the back initially. Then they are moved lower and to the anterior pubic region as labor progresses.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Placement over the abdominals is not the standard protocol.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This placement is too low and static; the placement should change as labor progresses.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This placement alone is insufficient to cover the different stages of labor pain.

subject: Other

question: A patient with chronic back pain is referred to physical therapy for application of a transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation unit. The parameters chosen by the therapist are set to provide a noxious stimulus described as an acupuncture type of stimulus. Which of the following lists of parameters produces this type of stimulation?

options.text: Low intensity, duration of 60 μsec, and a frequency of 50 Hz
High intensity, duration of 150 μsec, and a frequency of
Low intensity, duration of 150 μsec, and a frequency of 100 Hz
High intensity, duration of 150 μsec, and a frequency of 2 Hz

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: This type of stimulation is usually not well tolerated by patients with acute conditions. Acute conditions are usually treated by TENS with a high frequency, and chronic conditions can be treated with a low frequency (if tolerated by the patient). Treatments providing a noxious stimulus usually have a longer lasting effect.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This describes conventional (high-frequency) TENS, which is sensory-level, not acupuncture-like.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The question omits the frequency, but a high intensity suggests motor-level or noxious stimulation.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: This describes conventional (high-frequency) TENS.

subject: Other

question: A 63-year-old woman presents to physical therapy with a diagnosis of herpes zoster. The physician informs the physical therapist that the L5 dorsal root is involved and that a transcutaneous electrical neuromuscular stimulation (TENS) unit should be used to help control the pain. Where should the TENS unit electrodes be placed?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Herpes zoster involves a particular dorsal root and its ganglia. TENS unit electrodes should be placed over the involved dermatome (L5 in this case).

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: The posterior thigh is primarily the S1/S2 dermatome.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The lateral hip area is primarily the L2/L3 dermatome.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The anterior thigh is primarily the L2/L3 dermatome.

subject: Other

question: Use of functional electrical stimulation in patients with longstanding spinal cord injury does not improve
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Because functional electrical stimulation involves stimulating the paralyzed muscle groups, the same gains that one can expect from the “well” population can be carried over into the spinal cord injured patient. There has been no research to prove that osteopenia is reversed with electrical stimulation.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: FES cycling or walking can improve cardiovascular fitness.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: FES directly stimulates muscle contraction, which can increase muscle strength.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: FES can increase muscle mass and girth by repeatedly contracting the muscles.

subject: Neurology

question: A physician has ordered electrical stimulation to a 43-year-old male with complaints of sternocleidomastoid spasms. What is the appropriate course of action by the physical therapist?

options.text: Begin intervention with low frequency, high phase
Electrical stimulation in this area is a contraindication.
Begin intervention with high frequency, low phase duration electrical stimulation.
Use ultrasound only and do not contact the physician.

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The use of electrical stimulation near the carotid sinus is a contraindication. The physical therapist should always contact the physician if there is a change in an order as in choice D.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Applying electrical stimulation over the carotid sinus is contraindicated, regardless of the parameters.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Applying electrical stimulation over the carotid sinus is contraindicated, regardless of the parameters.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: The therapist should contact the physician to discuss the contraindication, not just switch to a different modality.

subject: Other

question: The physical therapist has decided to use functional electrical stimulation (FES) in order to help a spinal cord injured patient ambulate. What is the lowest spinal level injury that would be considered?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: A prerequisite for FES is an upper motor neuron lesion. Patients with flaccid paralysis are not suitable candidates for FES. The cauda equina begins below T11-T12.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This is an UMN lesion and a potential candidate.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This is an UMN lesion and a potential candidate.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: An L3-L4 injury is a lower motor neuron lesion, which results in flaccid paralysis. FES requires an intact peripheral nerve to stimulate the muscle.

subject: Neurology

question: A physical therapist is using a cold pack to decrease inflammation after a therapeutic exercise session. Which of the following areas needs to be monitored most closely during the ice pack application?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: The lateral knee would cause the most concern because the common peroneal nerve is superficial in this area. The medial elbow would be another area that would need extra care during ice application.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: The lumbar area has significant soft tissue covering any major nerves.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: The quadriceps muscle belly is a large area with no major superficial nerves at risk.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: While bony, the AC joint does not have a major superficial nerve that is at high risk of injury from ice.

subject: Other

question: In which of the following patient conditions would it be safe to apply spinal traction to help to decompress a spinal nerve root?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Spinal traction is contraindicated for patients with conditions that may cause spinal instability or fracture such as tumors, acute infections, osteoporosis, and rheumatoid arthritis.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Acute RA is an absolute contraindication due to inflammation and potential ligamentous instability.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Osteoporosis is a relative to absolute contraindication due to the risk of fracture.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: A spinal tumor is an absolute contraindication to traction.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Which of the following best describes the patient’s position when administering positional traction?

options.text: Hanging upside down on an inversion table (or with inversion boots)
Hanging by the hands (right side up) from an overhead bar
Side-lying with a pillow placed under one side of the lumbar spine
Sitting with head in a halter that is attached to an over-the-door traction system

rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Positional traction is used to alleviate pressure on an entrapped spinal nerve, which is usually a unilateral occurrence; thus, the side-lying position (nonpainful side) is most commonly used.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: This is mechanical gravity-assisted traction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.B: This is a form of gravity-assisted traction.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: This is a form of mechanical cervical traction.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: You plan to administer lumbar traction to a patient who has back pain and nerve root impingement. You determine from your history that this patient has no contraindications to the use of traction. What other piece of information are you required to have in order to determine the appropriate intensity for your traction treatment?
rationaleForCorrectAnswer: Although all pieces of information are important, the body weight is needed to help determine the maximum intensity for a lumbar traction treatment.

rationalesForIncorrectOptions.A: Age is a consideration for overall appropriateness but does not determine the specific force.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.C: Medications are important for the overall clinical picture but do not determine the traction force.
rationalesForIncorrectOptions.D: Pain rating helps guide the treatment and assess its effectiveness, but the force is calculated based on body weight.

subject: Musculoskeletal

question: Before a lumbar traction treatment, your patient tells you that his pain is located in his low back and right buttock. Your examination indicates a medium-sized herniated disk.
